And if they don't want to tell you, chances are, it's not even your place to butt in and spread rumors and lies about. And if you heard the truth from them, and still choose to change the story to either dig yourself a deeper hole for your lie, or just because you don't like them: why? Why would you want to create so much hate and drama in the circle, the group, or whatever it is? I don't get it.

Your words hold a lot more power and consequences than you think. You can ruin friendships, bonds, trusts and even lives. One simple lie or misunderstanding can spiderweb into something a lot bigger, but you're so filled with angst/hate and bent on creating drama and tea that you don't even see past it. And if you do see past it and still continue to do so? I'm sorry but you might be a sociopath. 

To those who listen and believe them, whether it be blindly, unintentional or with malicious thoughts: think twice before you accept it at face value. Ask the source directly. Talk to them about it. Get to know the other side before you judge them. You don't get to know someone by just hearing and reading things about them. You talk to them and get to know them yourselves. Who they are to these other people, aren't necessarily who they are to you.

Look, I'm not bringing hate to those who jump to conclusions, because I'm sure we all have done so in the past. I'm just saying, just be careful of what you say. On both ends. People can misconstrue what you say and it could turn into something completely different.

Here's a scenario:
You're a dude. You go to a club, you see some hot girl, walk up to her, she flirts with you, you buy her a drink, she disappears.
You gave her attention, you gave her a drink. She took them and left. Does she owe it to you to: keep flirting with you after getting the drink? No. Dance with you? No. Give you her number? No. Go home with you? No. Sleep with you? No.
A similar thing happens with guys who are overly nice to some girl they are attracted to. They keep doing favours for her and whatnot. The girl takes it, and isn't interested in them romantically, so then he asks her out and gets rejected. Again, she doesn't owe him a date or anything.
Eventually, most guys get it. It gets drilled into them. On reddit, on facebook, on snapchat, in the media, in real life, with memes, with jokes, with posts, with subreddits (r/niceguys), with articles. We all know about Nice Guy‚Ñ¢ and most guys get it that you shouldn't expect anything back.
But when it comes to girls, a lot of them don't get it at all. I don't understand why.
A guy was treating you well at first, you sleep with him, and he stops treating you well or disappears or just doesn't do whatever you were expecting. Does he owe it to you to: keep giving you the same attention? No. Sleep with you again? No. Date you? No.
Just like with the other scenarios, whether it's nice to do this or that is debatable and depends. I, personally, draw the line between asshole behaviour or not at explicitly (or implicitly in an obvious way) promising something and not doing it. BUT that is not the point. They still do not owe it to you to reciprocate or continue whatever they did before, just because you offered something. I kind of agree with Yulia about the post giving off, I guess, pretentious vibes about the whole matter, or in Yulia words, op acting as if he "found the mf grail," but I also feel she overestimates the general public's knowledge on Japan's involvement in WWII. From personal experience, I only was taught of Japan committing war crimes in high school, nothing more than that. Mind you that I am a POC from a predominantly white neighborhood, so my little anecdotes definitely may not be applicable to everyone else's experience, but if many others can relate to this than that says more about our education system than anything else. It wasn't until I entered into college that I found out about the extent of Japan's atrocities in the war; and looking back I feel that most of my education on WWII focused mainly on Europe and the Holocaust rather than other countries look those in Asia. Again, my own personal experience is my own and doesn't represent everyone's. So I think for the most part, and I can very much be wrong in making this claim, that mostly everyone knows of Japan's involvement and the crimes they committed during WWII, but don't truly understand the extent of it, some of the specific crimes they committed.

As for Jorge, I do agree that he has more of a say in the matter about the Latino community being oblivious to the extent of Japan's war crimes. I'm not Latino, but I've had my own fair share of people who aren't Chinese trying to tell me my own cultural community's background and struggles. Of course Jorge and I aren't the sole representatives of our respective cultures, but our own personal experiences along with many others in our communities can say a lot about how our community educates itself with other cultures' histories; it says a lot about how our communities interact with others and help each other through sharing information and communication. So for the most part, I do think Jorge has slightly more validity in explaining his own community's education of Japan's atrocities, but that's just my two cents there.

Anyways, the takeaway message, and this is just my own personal rambling, is that most of the general public knows of Japan's war crimes, but not the specifics of them nor the extent of them. More importantly, OP actually gained something from their experience traveling abroad, and trying to prove who is more entitled or valid in representing a claim on the general public's education is not only petty, but also futile. If the general public truly does not know about Japan's atrocities, than that says more on our education system and that should be the focus of our attention, not on who's more valid. Moreover, focus on OP learning about something and hopefully, if they are truly passionate about changing what they saw, OP takes steps to educate others around them about Japan's history in WWII.
